Text: This torrent contains all the files found in the virtual machine created by VMware 5.5.1. It was created using Jas's 10.4.7 OS X install disk with SSE2 enabled. This should work for most people even those with SSE3 machines. If your a total noob heres what you have to do. Go to vmware.com and download a program called vmplayer, its free. Then choose to open a VM, and direct it to the vmdk file that is within the torrent. This is obviously after unrar-ing the file. Good luck, post any problems.

2 things:

1. Is anyone working to get v10.4.10 functional in VMWare?  This version is required to run iWork '08 and it would be really cool to be able to run this software in my VM.

2. I ran into the reboot issue as well and I changed "Guest OS" to "winnt" and it worked just fine.  Now to figure out how to get a display setting in OS x86 higher than 1024 x 768.....
It appears that it doesnt work on AMD systems - i have the reboot problem on my AMD system and it started right up on my Intel system.

I appreciate the size of the RAR File.  Anything bigger would have been too big.  Any suggestions on the best way to extend the size of /dev/dsk0s1 from 5GB (with about 2.5GB useable) to something larger?

Any suggestions on how to run with a resolution higher than 1024 x 768?
Will this run under a Mac with the latest VMware Fusion?
It will work under VMWare fusion. Be sure to edit the FreeBSD.vmx file and change guestos to 'winnt'.

For those who want to expand the disk size...

1 - Create a new virtual disk with the wanted size.
2 - Use something like Symantec Ghost (win32) or G4L (Linux) to clone the  original virtual disk to the larger virtual disk...

G4L ISO Image: http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=119810&package_id=130506

Good Luck!

Some issues:  ===========

---> rebooting loop. 

Changed to guestOS = "winnt" in FreeBSD.vmx and this was solved.

---> network not worked first time, but using Mac OS network config wizard solved the problem. (vmware in "bridged" network configuration)

---> don't needed to remove FreeBSD.vmss  (haven't this file)
